mainmatter.p: An interesting example named omega combinator of beta reduction is the following: ( ( \lambda x. ( x \space x ) ) \space ( \lambda x. ( x \space x ) ) ) \to _ \beta ( ( \lambda x. ( x \space x ) ) \space ( \lambda x. ( x \space x ) ) ) The result of the beta reduction is the same term as the original term, and never terminates.
Refer to Type Theory and Formal Proof.

The idea to generalize the behavior of functions in mathematics and logic led to the development of the lambda calculus. The lambda calculus is a formal system for expressing computation based on function abstraction and application using variable binding and substitution. In dealing with functions there are two construction principles and one evalutaion rule.
Construction Principles: note that expressions do not force to be meaningful.
Function Abstraction: \lambda x.M
Function Application: M N, this only produces a new expression, in which the function has not yet been executed.
Evaluation Rule
Beta Reduction: ( \lambda x.M)N \to M[x:=N] The beta reduction makes use of the substitution M[x:=N] which represents the result of replacing all free occurrences of x in M with N. Note that the application is left associative, that is, MNP means (MN)P. And application has the highest precedence, that is, \lambda x.MN means \lambda x.(MN).

The multi-argument function \lambda x_1 \ldots x_n.M is defined as \lambda x_1.( \lambda x_2.( \ldots ( \lambda x_n.M) \ldots )) (right associative), that is, simulated by a sequence of single-argument functions. The later function is called curried function and the process of transforming a multi-argument function into a sequence of single-argument functions is called currying.
Expressions in the lambda calculus is called terms. The set of terms is denoted \Lambda.

Let \Lambda be the set of lambda terms. Then \Lambda is defined inductively as follows: (V is the set of variables)
Variable: \forall x \in V, x \in \Lambda
Abstraction: \forall x \in V, M \in \Lambda , \lambda x.M \in \Lambda
Application: \forall M,N \in \Lambda , (MN) \in \Lambda
Another way to define \Lambda is to use the following grammar (The 3 possibilities are separated by |): \Lambda = V | \lambda V. \Lambda | \Lambda \Lambda
With the following recursive definition we can determine what the subterms of a give \lambda \text {-term} are. Here we use a concept named multiset.
The definition above uses a notation \equiv which means syntactic equality here.

li.tex: \text {Sub} ( \lambda x. ( x \space x ) ) = \{ \lambda x. ( x \space x ) , ( x \space x ) ,x,x \}

mainmatter.p: The substerm mapping satisfies the following lemma.

Variable occurrences in a \lambda \text {-term} can be divided into 3 categories:
Bound Occurrences: x is bound in M if x is the argument of an abstraction in M.
Free Occurrences: x is free in M if x is not bound by any abstraction in M.
Binding Occurrences: something after a lambda notation \lambda We mainly focus on the free variables of a term.
The \lambda \text {-term} M is closed if \text {FV} (M) = \emptyset. A closed \lambda \text {-term} is also called a combinator. The set of all combinators is denoted by \Lambda ^0.

frontmatter.title: Untyped Lambda Calculus â€º Alpha conversion

mainmatter.p: Functions in \lambda \text {-calculus} have the property that the name of the binding variables is irrelevant. In order to describe this equality we need to define a relation called \alpha \text {-conversion} or \alpha \text {-equivalence}, which is based on the process of renaming binding variables.

Let M ^{ x \to y } be the result of replacing all free occurrences of x in M with y. The relation renaming is expression with the symbol =_ \alpha: \lambda x.M =_ \alpha \lambda y. M ^{ x \to y } if y \not \in \text {FV} (M) and y is not a binding variable in M.
The definition of renaming should be extended to more general terms.

The \alpha equivalence is a relation between \lambda \text {-term}, defined as follows:
Renaming: \lambda x. M =_ \alpha \lambda y. M ^{ x \to y } if y \not \in \text {FV} (M) and y is not a binding variable in M.
Compatibility: If M =_ \alpha N then \lambda x.M =_ \alpha \lambda x.N and ML =_ \alpha NL, LM =_ \alpha LN.
Reflexivity: M =_ \alpha M.
Symmetry: If M =_ \alpha N then N =_ \alpha M.
Transitivity: If M =_ \alpha N and N =_ \alpha L then M =_ \alpha L.
The first principle is the basis of alpha equivalence, which is the same as renaming. The last 3 properties ensures that =_ \alpha is an equivalence relation.
If M =_ \alpha N then we say M and N are \alpha \text {-equivalent} or \alpha \text {-convertible}. M is an \alpha \text {-variant} of N and vice versa.
In previous sections we informally mentioned the concept of substitution. Now we give a precise formulation

The substitution is defined by the following rules:
M [ x := N ] : \equiv N
y [ x := N ] : \equiv y if y \not \equiv x
(PQ) [ x := N ] : \equiv ( P [ x := N ] )( Q [ x := N ] )
( \lambda y.P) [ x := N ] : \equiv \lambda z. P ^{ y \to z } [ x := N ] if \lambda z. P ^{ y \to z } =_ \alpha \lambda y.P and z \not \in \text {FV} (N) The terms with form P [ x := N ] are not \lambda \text {-term}, but we can regard them as a meta notation that appears in the substitution process and the result contains no such terms.
Renaming can be considered as a special case of substitution. We can show that M ^{ x \to u } =_ \alpha M [ x := u ] if the conditions of renaming are satisfied.
We may do sequential substitution in a term, that is, doing a number of substitutions consecutively. And we have the following lemma, which states that the order of substitution is important.
Let x \not \equiv y and assume x \not \in \text {FV} (L). Then L[y:=N][x:=M] \equiv L[x:=M][y:=N[x:=M]].

As we have seen, the relation =_ \alpha is an equivalence relation. Hence we can define the set of equivalence classes of terms with respect to =_ \alpha. Now we can identify a term with its equivalence class. We still use \equiv for syntactic equality modulo \alpha \text {-equivalence}.
\alpha \text {-equivalence} is a congruence relation, which means that it is conserved by elementary process of term construction.

Let L =_ \alpha M and N =_ \alpha P.
LN =_ \alpha MP
\lambda x.L =_ \alpha \lambda x.M
L [ x := N ] =_ \alpha M [ x := P ]

frontmatter.title: Untyped Lambda Calculus â€º Barendregt Convention

mainmatter.p: The Barendregt Convention states that we should avoid using the same variable name in different abstractions. This is to avoid the confusion of free variables. It states that we choose the names for the binding variables in a \lambda \text {-term} in such a manner that they are all different, and each of them differs from all free variables occurring in the term.

frontmatter.title: Untyped Lambda Calculus â€º Beta Reduction

mainmatter.p: Since we have formally defined the substitution, we can rephrase the reduction as a relation on \lambda \text {-term}, namely \beta \text {-reduction}.

One step beta reduction (\to _ \beta) is defined as follows:
Basis: ( \lambda x.M)N \to _ \beta M [ x := N ]
Compatibility: If M \to _ \beta N then \lambda x.M \to _ \beta \lambda x.N, ML \to _ \beta NL and LM \to _ \beta LN.
The term of the form ( \lambda x.M)N is called a redex (reducible expression). The term of the form M [ x := N ] is called the contractum (of the redex).

An interesting example named omega combinator of beta reduction is the following: ( ( \lambda x. ( x \space x ) ) \space ( \lambda x. ( x \space x ) ) ) \to _ \beta ( ( \lambda x. ( x \space x ) ) \space ( \lambda x. ( x \space x ) ) ) The result of the beta reduction is the same term as the original term, and never terminates.
We can often perform a sequence of beta reductions. This leads to the definition.

The (zero-or-more-step) beta reduction (\twoheadrightarrow _{ \beta }) is a generalized version of the one step beta reduction. M \twoheadrightarrow _{ \beta } N if there exists n \geq 0 and there are terms M_0,M_1, \ldots ,M_n such that M_0=M, M_n=N and M_i \to _ \beta M_{i+1} for 0 \leq i<n. In other words there exists a chain of one-step beta reductions from M to N. M \equiv M_0 \to _ \beta M_1 \to _ \beta \cdots \to _ \beta M_n \equiv N

ul.li: Compatibility: \twoheadrightarrow _{ \beta } extends \to _ \beta, i.e. if M \to _ \beta N then M \twoheadrightarrow _{ \beta } N.
Transitivity: M \twoheadrightarrow _{ \beta } N \land N \twoheadrightarrow _{ \beta } P \implies M \twoheadrightarrow _{ \beta } P

mainmatter.p: We begin with the schema of iteration and then proceed the more complex schema of primitive recursion and general recursion. Refer to TAPL.

frontmatter.title: Primitive Recursion in Lambda Calculus â€º Function Composition

tree.mainmatter: Giving two functions f, g we can compose then to get a new function f \circ g = f(g(x)). Using \lambda-notation, we can define the composition of two functions as follows: f \circ g = \lambda x.f(g(x)) And the composition operation is also a lambda abstraction. \circ = B = \lambda f. \lambda g. \lambda x.f(g(x)) Composing identity function with any function does not change the function. We expect the following equation to hold: f \circ I = f = I \circ f where I is the identity function. This can be verified by the following calculation: \begin {align*} B \space f \space I &= ( \lambda f. \lambda g. \lambda x.f(g(x))) \space f \space I \\ & \to _ \beta \lambda g. \lambda x.f(g(x)) \space I \\ & \to _ \beta \lambda x.f(I(x)) \\ & \to _ \beta \lambda x.f(x) \\ & =_ \eta f \end {align*} The last step requires an extensional equality, which is the called eta-conversion. \text {for} \space x \not \in \text {FV} (f) , \lambda x.f(x) =_ \eta f It makes more sense to use the equation from right to left called eta-expansion (And more discipline has to be imposed or expansion does not terminate).

frontmatter.title: Primitive Recursion in Lambda Calculus â€º Non-termination

mainmatter.p: The well-known divergent combinator implies that the lambda calculus is not strongly normalizing.

However, we can always compute a normal form if one exists. Though there are many reduction strategies, there is a complete one for expressions that have normal form. This kind of reduction strategy is called normal order reduction or leftmost-outermost reduction. It scans through the expression from left to right and when it find a redex, it reduces it by applying beta reduction and returns to the beginning.
The notation of leftmost-outermost reduction is closely related to the notion of call-by-name evaluation in programming languages. (A little more distance to call-by-need evaluation in Haskell)
In contrast, call-by-value evaluation is not complete, which would reduce the argument of a function before applying beta reduction.

frontmatter.title: Primitive Recursion in Lambda Calculus â€º Church-Rosser Property

tree.mainmatter: The outcome of a computation e is its normal form. It is naturally to ask the question whether the normal form is unique. The key to this question is the Church-Rosser property or confluence: If e \to ^* e_1 and e \to ^* e_2, then there exists a term e_3 such that e_1 \to ^* e_3 \space \text {and} \space e_2 \to ^* e_3 This implies the uniqueness of the normal form.

frontmatter.title: Primitive Recursion in Lambda Calculus â€º Representing Natural Numbers

mainmatter.p: We can represent natural numbers in lambda calculus by using the Church numerals or Church encoding. The two abstractions should be related in some ways: one x stands for zero and the other f stands for the successor function.

The Church numeral n is a function that takes two arguments f and x and applies f to x n times. The Church numeral 0 is defined as the identity function \lambda f. \lambda x.x. The Church numeral 1 is defined as the successor of 0: 1 = \lambda f. \lambda x.f(x) The Church numeral 2 is defined as the successor of 1: 2 = \lambda f. \lambda x.f(f(x)) And so on.
The Church numeral n is defined as the successor of n-1: n = \lambda f. \lambda x.f^n(x) where f^n(x) means applying f to x n times.
The successor function is defined as follows: S = \lambda n. \lambda f. \lambda x.f(n \space f \space x)

mainmatter.tex: \begin {align*} S \space n &= ( \lambda n. \lambda f. \lambda x.f(n \space f \space x)) \space n \\ & \to _ \beta \lambda f. \lambda x.f(n \space f \space x) \\ & \to _ \beta \lambda f. \lambda x.f^n(x) \\ & \to _ \beta n+1 \end {align*}

mainmatter.p: Using the iteration property we can define mathematical functions over the natural numbers in lambda calculus. The addition of two Church numerals m and n is defined as follows: m+n = \lambda n. \lambda k. n \space S \space k
The multiplication of two Church numerals m and n is defined by iterating the addition function m times: m*n = \lambda n. \lambda k. n \space (k + ) \space 0
The exponentiation of two Church numerals m and n is defined as follows: m^n = \lambda m. \lambda n. n \space (m *) \space 1

frontmatter.title: Primitive Recursion in Lambda Calculus â€º The Schema of Iteration

mainmatter.p: As we saw before, a natural number n is represented by a function that iterates its first argument n times on its second argument. n = \lambda g. \lambda c.g^n(c) Another way to specify such a function schematically is \begin {align*} f \space0 &= c \\ f (n+1) &= g \space (f \space n) \end {align*} If such a function satisfies such a schema of iteration, then it can be defined in the lambda calculus on Church numerals as f = \lambda n.n \space g \space c This definition is total which means it is defined for all natural numbers. Let's define the multiplication again \begin {align*} m*0 &= 0 \\ m*(n+1) &= m + (m*n) \end {align*} To fit our schema of iteration, we can define the multiplication by abstracting over k: \begin {align*} \text {times} \space 0 &= \lambda k.0 \\ \text {times} \space (n+1) &= \lambda k.k + ( \text {times} \space n \space k) \end {align*} where the c and g are \begin {align*} c &= \lambda k.0 \\ g &= \lambda r. \lambda k.k+(r \space k) \end {align*} and we obtain \text {times} = \lambda n.n( \lambda rk. k + (r \space k))( \lambda k.0)

frontmatter.title: Primitive Recursion in Lambda Calculus â€º The Schema of Primitive Recursion

mainmatter.p: Everything appears simply until we think of a very simple function, the predecessor function \text {pred} defined by \begin {align*} \text {pred} \space 0 = 0 \\ \text {pred} \space (n+1) = n \end {align*} What we would need is the schema of primitive recursion \begin {align*} f \space 0 &= c \\ f \space (n+1) &= g \space n \space (f \space n) \end {align*} With which we can define the predecessor function by g = \lambda x. \lambda y.x

frontmatter.title: Primitive Recursion in Lambda Calculus â€º Define predecessor function

tree.mainmatter: The key idea is to gain access to n in the schema of primitive recursion by rebuilding it during the iteration. \text {pred}_2 \space n = \langle n, \text {pred} \space n \rangle The key step is to express the definition by a schema of iteration rather than primitive recursion. \text {pred}_2 \space 0 = \langle 0, 0 \rangle We need a helper function for the successor case \text {letPair} \space \langle e_1,e_2 \rangle \space k = k \space e_1 \space e_2 This function passes the elements of the pair to a continuation k. \text {pred}_2 (n+1) = \text {letPair} \space ( \text {pred}_2 \space n) \space ( \lambda xy. \langle x+1, x \rangle )

frontmatter.title: Primitive Recursion in Lambda Calculus â€º Define Pairs

tree.mainmatter: Now we need to define pairs and \text {letPair}. The idea is to simply abstract over the continuation itself. \begin {align*} \langle x,y \rangle &= \lambda k.k \space x \space y \\ \text {pair} &= \lambda x. \lambda y. \lambda k.k \space x \space y \\ \text {letPair} &= \lambda p.p \end {align*} The letPair is not really needed here.

frontmatter.title: Primitive Recursion in Lambda Calculus â€º Summary

tree.mainmatter: Summarizing the above and we obtain the full definition of the predecessor function. \begin {align*} \text {pred}_2 &= \lambda n.n \space ( \lambda p.p ( \lambda xy. \text {pair} \space (x+1) \space x)) \space \text {pair} ( \space 0 \space 0) \\ \text {pred} &= \lambda n. ( \text {pred}_2 \space n) \space ( \lambda xy.y) \end {align*}

frontmatter.title: Primitive Recursion in Lambda Calculus â€º General Primitive Recursion

tree.mainmatter: The general case of primitive recursion follows by a similar pattern. We begin by defining a function f_2: f_2 \space n = \langle n, f \space n \rangle We can define f_2 using the schema of iteration \begin {align*} f_2 \space 0 &= \langle 0, c \rangle \\ f_2 \space (n+1) &= \text {letPair} \space (f_2 \space n) \space ( \lambda xy. \langle x+1, g \space x \space y \rangle ) \\ f \space n &= \text {letPair} \space (f_2 \space n) \space ( \lambda xy.y) \end {align*}

mainmatter.p: When computing over natural numbers we can restrict the functions that can be formed in schematic ways to obtain a language in which all functions terminate. Because if c and g are terminating then so is f formed from them by primitive recursion.
